title: Sha bi - cultural learnings for make benefit glorious nation of oce LoL
body:
Trigger warning - this post is a little raw and deals with swear words seen in OCE chat. This is not a troll post - I have often wondered why"sha bi" gets thrown around so much.

So I did a bit of research - it basically means "stupid c\*nt"

> > 屄 bī (also 逼、比、B) = c\*nt
> 傻屄 shǎbī = stupid c\*nt
> 骚屄 sāobī = bitch (lit. "lewd c\*nt")
> 臭屄 chòubī = stinking c\*nt
> 烂屄 lànbī = rotten c\*nt
> 阴道 yīndào = vagina (scientific)
http://dirtychinesewords.blogspot.com.au/

So every time our fellow players who converse in the english form of written chinese say "sha bi", they're calling you a stupid c\*nt.

Or cao, which means "f\*ck", which therefore follows on that cao ni means "f\*ck you".

Or my particular fav: 操你祖宗十八代 cào nǐ zǔzōng shíbā dài = f\*ck your ancestors to the eighteenth generation.

Cross cultural communication is a beautiful thing.

http://www.mynewchinesewife.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/chinese-girlfriend.jpg

replies.body: Wait, so according to this, in Dynasty Warriors, Cao Cao's name literally translates to 'fuck fuck'?

not as easy as that.

Mandarin is a tonal language which means some words have a similar sound to us round eyes but there is a subtle intonation which gives the word a different meaning.

A very good example can be found here:

http://www.yellowbridge.com/onlinelit/stonelion.php

The below is an actual poem / tongue twister in mandarin. You can see the little accents above the words - that dictates the tone used to pronounce it. The english translation of the poem is below the pinyin.

« Shī Shì shí shī shǐ »

Shíshì shīshì Shī Shì, shì shī, shì shí shí shī.

Shì shíshí shì shì shì shī.

Shí shí, shì shí shī shì shì.

Shì shí, shì Shī Shì shì shì.

Shì shì shì shí shī, shì shǐ shì, shǐ shì shí shī shìshì.

Shì shí shì shí shī shī, shì shíshì.

Shíshì shī, Shì shǐ shì shì shíshì.

Shíshì shì, Shì shǐ shì shí shì shí shī.

Shí shí, shǐ shí shì shí shī shī, shí shí shí shī shī.

Shì shì shì shì.

English:

« Lion-Eating Poet in the Stone Den »

In a stone den was a poet called Shi Shi, who was a lion addict, and had resolved to eat ten lions.

He often went to the market to look for lions.

At ten o’clock, ten lions had just arrived at the market.

At that time, Shi had just arrived at the market.

He saw those ten lions, and using his trusty arrows, caused the ten lions to die.

He brought the corpses of the ten lions to the stone den.

The stone den was damp. He asked his servants to wipe it.

After the stone den was wiped, he tried to eat those ten lions.

When he ate, he realized that these ten lions were in fact ten stone lion corpses.

Try to explain this matter.

> [{quoted}](name=Essembie,realm=OCE,application-id=Ntey9fRZ,discussion-id=1RtjheTb,comment-id=00000000,timestamp=2016-09-22T13:37:32.794+0000)
>
> not as easy as that.
>

> 
> A very good example can be found here:
>

> 
> The below is an actual poem / tongue twister in mandarin. You can see the little accents above the words - that dictates the tone used to pronounce it. The english translation of the poem is below the pinyin.
> 
> « Shī Shì shí shī shǐ »
> 
> Shíshì shīshì Shī Shì, shì shī, shì shí shí shī.
> 
> Shì shíshí shì shì shì shī.
> 
> Shí shí, shì shí shī shì shì.
> 
> Shì shí, shì Shī Shì shì shì.
> 
> Shì shì shì shí shī, shì shǐ shì, shǐ shì shí shī shìshì.
> 
> Shì shí shì shí shī shī, shì shíshì.
> 
> Shíshì shī, Shì shǐ shì shì shíshì.
> 
> Shíshì shì, Shì shǐ shì shí shì shí shī.
> 
> Shí shí, shǐ shí shì shí shī shī, shí shí shí shī shī.
> 
> Shì shì shì shì.
> 
> English:
> 
> « Lion-Eating Poet in the Stone Den »
> 
> In a stone den was a poet called Shi Shi, who was a lion addict, and had resolved to eat ten lions.
> 
> He often went to the market to look for lions.
> 
> At ten o’clock, ten lions had just arrived at the market.
> 
> At that time, Shi had just arrived at the market.
> 
> He saw those ten lions, and using his trusty arrows, caused the ten lions to die.
> 
> He brought the corpses of the ten lions to the stone den.
> 
> The stone den was damp. He asked his servants to wipe it.
> 
> After the stone den was wiped, he tried to eat those ten lions.
> 
> When he ate, he realized that these ten lions were in fact ten stone lion corpses.
> 
> Try to explain this matter.

HAHA SHAME ON'IM. I hope he got cracked teeth and indigestion :s

My theory was better.

But i bet they still don't get banned or anything.

This will be good for future reference. Guess I've got some Mandarin to learn (Mandarin, right?).

Also, you need to be using the back slash "\" so that the asterisks "*" don't "disappear" and create italic font. You've got some missing asterisks in the post with italics taking place where it shouldn't.
yeah the asterisks got me in this post.
